name: butylcyclopentane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.

name: butylcyclopentane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit for this compound is cyclopentane, which has a melting point of approximately -93.9 degrees Celsius. The butyl group (a chain of four carbons) adds to the molecular weight and the van der Waals forces. This functional group would generally raise the melting point. However, long alkyl chains can also create a more flexible molecule that can pack less efficiently, which might lower or only slightly increase the melting point. Ethyl groups have been found to raise the melting point by roughly 20 degrees over the corresponding alkane, but longer alkyl groups have diminishing incremental effects. Approximating the effect of a butyl group as slightly higher than an ethyl group, an increase by 12 degrees might be expected.

name: butylcyclopentane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit for this compound is cyclopentane, which has a melting point of approximately -93.9 degrees Celsius. The addition of a butyl group (which consists of four carbon atoms) will contribute to an increase in the melting point due to the increment in molecular weight and since larger nonpolar groups can enhance the van der Waals forces between molecules. However, this increase may not be as impactful considering longer alkyl chains can also lead to increased molecular flexibility and potentially hinder efficient packing in solid-state, which is conducive to a lower melting point. The effect of a butyl group is expected to be more modest compared to smaller alkyl groups; considering a small incremental increase, as an estimate, might raise the melting point by approximately 3 to 5 degrees Celsius over cyclopentane.

name: butylcyclopentane
source: American Petroleum Institute. Research Project 44; Selected Values of Properties of Hydrocarbons and Related Compounds. Texas A & M University; College Station; TX; 1973.
Reason: The compound butylcyclopentane can be thought of as the combination of a cyclopentane ring and a butyl group. The basic unit, cyclopentane, has a melting point of -94°C. Adding a butyl group (–C4H9) to the ring increases the molecular weight and surface area, leading to increased London dispersion forces between molecules, which tends to increase the melting point. However, the linear alkyl chain can also cause an increase in the flexibility of the molecule, which may slightly reduce the melting point. Estimating the contribution of the butyl group to be around -6 to -4 degrees due to these mixed effects, adjusting the baseline of cyclopentane yields a predicted melting point.
